toolittledurability: Your tool requires {0} durability to do this.
WorkstationTypeNotDesignated: Workstation {0} does not have workstation type designated in blocktype
indappledgroves:item-handbooktext-splitt: These blades are used in the log splitter. Slab blades are for making log slabs, and cross blades for making firewood from logs.
indappledgroves:block-handbooktext-pan: Start by creating a a debarked log slab and placing it flat on the ground. You then use hewing tool to craft it into a wooden pan.
block-handbooktext-logsplitter:
The Log Splitter is a new tool for efficiently making fire wood. It's can also be used to create log slabs. To use the logsplitter, place it, and install a slab blade to make slabs, or a cross blade to make firewood.

Processing a log put in a logsplitter requires using a tool, such as the splitting maul that has the pounding tool mode. The log splitter is best used for making firewood. It splits logs slightly slower than using a maul to split the same log, but directly create firewood. This makes it a faster option for creating firewood than the chopping block.
Do note that blades have durability, and will need to be replaced every so often. Neither the material of the blade or log splitter will influence the speed at which firewood is produced. However, the material of the blade does affect the blades durability.
block-handbooktext-barkbasket: With each weave of the bark, we are closer to home. - On Basket Weaving These baskets are made wrought from the soaked bark of any tree. This timeless technology has survived the rot, and is a cornerstone of Seraph's looking for convenient storage. Bark has a long history of being used for the making of baskets in areas all over the world. Evidence of baskets can be found in cultures ranging from the Sami of the Sapmi region, the Salsih, Chilkat, and other Native American Tribes of the American Northwest, and countless others.
block-handbooktext-choppingblock: Recipe Type: In World Tool Mode: Hewing Ingredients: Any log slab Tools: adze, Grub Axe
block-handbooktext-choppingblock2: Before Enlightenment - Chop Wood, Carry Water, After Enlightenment- Chop Wood, Carry Water - Zen Proverb Made by laying any log slab flat on the ground, and hewing it with an adze or other hewing tool, chopping blocks are the foundation of the serious woodsmans set of workstations. This workstation provides an improvement in the effectiveness of your tools. Work performed on a chopping block is generally faster than on the ground. In addition, there may be certain recipes that can only be performed with the help of a chopping block. For those intending to work with large amounts of wood, it should be the first workstation you acquire.
block-handbooktext-logslab: Recipe Type: In World & Workstation Crafting Tool Mode: Chopping Ingredients: Any Log Tools: Axes
block-handbooktext-logslab2: The first stage on the way to making fire wood. They can be made on a chopping block or on the ground. The target log must be upright, with the trunk exposed, rather than bark up. Log slabs, when placed flat, can be hewn into chopping blocks, when upright, they can be chopped into firewood, or hewn to create stripped log slabs and produce two bark.
block-handbooktext-strippedlog: Nude bodies like peeled logs sometimes give off a sweetest odor, man and woman under the trees in full excess - William Carlos Williams Stripped logs are created by hewing a barked log. Can then be split into stripped log slabs. How To Create Recipe Type: In World & Workstation Crafting Tool Mode: Hewing Ingredients: Any Log Common Tools: Adze, Grub Axe
block-handbooktext-sawhorse: At the left, the ax; at the right, the saw. The ax in the block, the saw on the sawhorse. Sawdust smothers the walk. Sitting in the shed to watch the rain come down. - Paol Keineg
indappledgroves:block-handbooktext-sawbu: The Wind Was Sawing, And The Sawdust Was Whirling - Charles Dickens The sawbuck is a workstation that is primarily used for sawing operations, making the process go a little faster, and putting a little less wear and tear on your tool.
indappledgroves:block-handbooktext-barkb: There's the whitebox and pine on the ridges afar, Where the iron-bark, blue-gum, and peppermint are; There is many another, but dearest to me, And the king of them all was the stringy-bark tree.. - Stringy-Bark Tree Poem by Henry Lawson Creating a dry bark bundle is a simple process. Simply shift-right-click the ground in one of the four corners of a block with a handful of dry bark to create a ground storage. Fill the remaining three spaces with the same kind of bark, and then click in the center with a fifth piece to make a dry bark bundle. Your bark bundle is now ready for processing. Pick it up and place it on a block covered by water to begin the soaking process. 24 hours later you'll have a soaked bark bundle. Pick it up and you'll recieve 5 pieces of soaked bark, ready to be made into a basket.
indappledgroves:item-handbooktext-soaked: And when sawn-timber homes were built out in the West, Then for walls and for ceilings its wood was the best; And for shingles and palings to last while men be, There was nothing on earth like the stringy-bark tree. - Stringy-Bark Tree Poem by Henry Lawson Soaked bark is obtained by placing a bark bundle into water by right-clicking a water covered block. This will place the dry bark bundle, turning it into a soaking bark bundle. Over time, it will convert into a soaked bark bundle. Simply right click the soaked bark bundle to pick up 5 soaked bark. Soaked bark is a versatile material perfect for crafting into useful containers, the bark baskets. If you also have Taska's Ancient Tools installed, then you will also need to soak soaked barkbirchbark to make salves.
indappledgroves:item-handbooktext-firewo: Beechwood fires are bright and clear If the logs are kept a year, Chestnut's only good they say, If for logs 'tis laid away. - The Firewood Poem by Lady Celia Congreve In Dappled Groves Uses: Recipe Type: In World & Workstation Crafting Tool Mode: Chopping Ingredients: Barked or Debarked Log Slab Common Tools: Axe, Forest Axe, Maul, Grub Axe Workstation: Chopping Block or Ground
indappledgroves:item-handbooktext-stick: I was far off in the forest When I found the perfect stick I knew that it was perfect Not too skinny, Not too thick -Amy Ludwig VanDerwater In Dappled Groves Uses: Recipe Type: In World & Workstation Crafting Tool Mode: Chopping Ingredients: Firewood Common Tools: Axe, Forest Axe, Maul, Grub Axe Workstation: Chopping Block or Ground You can use any axe to chop a piece of fire wood on the ground or on a chopping block to create sticks.
indappledgroves:block-handbooktext-debar: In Dappled Groves Uses: Recipe Type: In World & Workstation Crafting Tool Mode: Hewing Ingredients: Any Log Common Tools: adze, Grub Axe Workstation: Chopping Block or Ground
indappledgroves:block-handbooktext-suppo: In Dappled Groves Uses: Recipe Type: In World & Workstation Crafting Tool Mode: Hewing Ingredients: Any Debarked Log Common Tools: adze, Grub Axe Workstation: Saw Buck
item-handbooktext-grubaxe: A grub axe has a long handle and a stout head combining a vertical axe blade with a horizontal adze. This makes it a flexible tool capable of chopping or hewing.
item-handbooktext-forestaxe: With aching limbs and tortured back, We'd listen for the tree to crack. And there would be a thunderous sound, As it came crashing to the ground. - George Savige The distinguishing feature of forest axes is a long, rounded edge, with a flat elongated axe head. Forest Axes are specially designed to cut across the grain of the wood fibres, for example when felling and limbing. This makes them exceptionally good for chopping down trees, though they perform poorly when attempting to chop lumber into log slabs, fire wood, and sticks.
item-handbooktext-maul: This tool has a heavy head with a thick chopping blade making it perfect for splitting logs into slabs. These can be further split into fire wood, and from there into sticks.
item-handbooktext-drybark: Bark from trees is useful for making bark baskets. This is accomplished by fashioning them into bark bundles and soaking them for 24 hours to produce soaked bark.
indappledgrovesguide-inworldcrafting-tex: In-World Crafting In-World Crafting works to remove the dependence on the crafting grid to create a more immersive experience. In Dappled Groves applies this principle by providing two new mechanics to your woodworking adventures. Ground Processing The first mechanic is the ability to process wood without the grid. You can place a log, log slab, or piece of firewood on the ground and interact with it with a tool such as an axe, adze, or saw. The results depend on the tool used and the selected tool mode. For instance, a Grub Axe set to hewing used on a log will produce bark, while selecting the chopping tool mode will result in log slabs. Workstations Workstations are the second mechanic. These currently include the chopping block and saw buck. These workstations serve to provide a boost to efficiency when processing recipes on them. Like before, the tool mode of your tool alters the results. Working materials on or off of a workstation is done the same way. Simply target the block and hold down the right-mouse button. The working animation will begin, and soon you'll see your results. Wood types vary in their hardness, so the time required may vary. Pine is a softer wood, and will process quickly. Ebony is one of the world's hardest woods, and will take significantly longer, especially with stone tools.
indappledgrovesguide-workstations-text: Workstation Crafting ‘And while I worked it made me think Of timber’s varied doom; One inch where people eat and drink, The next inch in a tomb. - “The Workbox” by Thomas Hardy Workstations are blocks that add an interactive element to producing resources. In Dappled Groves adds two such workstations, the chopping block and the sawbuck. Workstations Chopping Block The chopping block is the most basic of workstations, made by using a hewing tool such as an adze or a grub axe on a log slab laid flat on the ground. The chopping block is currently used for a number of chopping and hewing processes. You can process logs into log slabs, those into firewood, and those into sticks. These processes can also be done on the ground, but the chopping block speeds up the process. Saw Buck The sawbuck becomes available after you craft boards on the ground with a saw. As with the chopping block, it speeds up processes performed on it, and is used for sawing logs into boards, and hewing them into support beams.
indappledgrovesguide-toolmodes-text: Tool Modes Tool modes provide options in how a tool is used, and can be changed by pressing the F key while holding a tool that has them. In vanilla, tool modes can be seen with the chisel and prospecting pick. This mod adds these options to other tools to provide more dynamic crafting opportunities when combined with different materials and workstations. Basic Concepts Tool modes in this mod provide access to different recipes and therefore different outputs based the tool, crafting station, and input. Three different tool modes have been implemented as of this version, with a fourth presently disabled and a fifth being planned. Not all tools will have access to the same tool modes, nor will all tools that have access to a tool mode be guaranteed to be effective at the indicated process. Some tools are simply better at some things than others. For instance, you can hew wood with the backside of a grub axe, but it's not as effective as the same tier adze will be. Tool Modes Chopping: Used when chopping wood into slabs, firewood, and sticks. May be changed to 'splitting' in a future revision. Found in any form of axe, including forest axe, grub axes, and mauls. Hewing: Used when shaping wood or 'peeling' it, such as when removing bark. Currently used only for peeling bark, creating chopping blocks from slabs, and making beams on the sawbuck. Found in any adze or Grub Axe.' Sawing: Used by saws, when making boards out of logs. Found in, unsurprisingly, the saw. Pounding: This tool mode is available in the splitting maul, and is used with the log splitter. to produce fire wood efficiently. It is also used for making log slabs.
item-handbooktext-firewood: Can be made by chopping a log slab after placing on the ground, or on a chopping block. Can be placed on the ground or a chopping block and processed into sticks by chopping them with an axe or other chopping tool.
indappledgroves:indappledgrovesguide-woo: Good timber does not grow with ease, The stronger wind, the stronger trees; The further sky, the greater length; The more the storm, the more the strength. - Good Timber by Douglas Malloch Wood Resistances and Wood Working Woods in In Dappled Groves have different wood resistance by type. This influences how quickly you can fell trees and process wood materials.The resistance of the wood, the workstation you're using, and the effectivenss of your tool all play into how quickly a tree can be felled and the wood then worked. Wood hardness is derived from the Janka Hardness test, and accordingly represent an approximate simulation of VS woods in relation to one another in RL. Not to be confused with this test. You're welcome, I'm a nerd. Wood Resistance in Order By Mod Softest To Hardest Vanilla: Redwood, Larch, Pine, Kapok, Walnut, Birch, Oak, Maple, Acacia, Purpleheart, Ebony Wildcraft Trees And Shrubs: Bearnut, Chlorocibora, Poplar, Catalpa, (Vanilla: Redwood), Willow, Spruce, Douglas Fir, Elm, Sycamore, Red Cedar, Cedar, Ginkgo, Eucalyptus, Tuja, Saxaul, Empress Tree, Beech, Kauri, (Vanilla: Kapok), Blue Majoe, Satin Ash, Ghost Gum, (Vanilla: Walnut), Yew, Honey Locust, Sal, Ohia, Banyan, Dalbergia, Mahogany, Jacaranda, Umini, (Vanilla: Acacia), Petrified, Guajacum, (Vanilla: Ebony)
indappledgroves:item-handbooktext-plank: Oak boards where the carved ferns mingle, Monks’ shrines in the wilderness, Snug little huts in the dingle, All things that the sad poets bless. -Amy Ludwig VanDerwater In Dappled Groves Uses: Recipe Type: In World & Workstation Crafting Tool Mode: Sawing Ingredients: Any Log Common Tools: Saw Workstation: sawbuck or Ground You can use any saw tool to saw any log on the ground or on a sawbuck to make boards.
